newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech cbank says to keep current exchange policy.
newsitem.headline: Czech cbank says to keep current exchange policy.

text.p: The Czech National Bank (CNB) said on Friday that it would stick to its current exchange rate policy and that the exchange rate was manageable within the current +/-7.5 percent fluctuation band.
"We are still keeping our exchange rate policy, it means to maintain the exchange rate within the fluctuation band," CNB Vice-governor Jan Vit told Reuters.
"We still think that the proper level of the exchange rate is within the fluctuation band, and we are using our own instruments including intervention to keep it in," he added.

Vit confirmed that the CNB had intervened on the market for the second consecutive day on Friday to support the crown, but that it was only "small amounts". "The pressure on the crown is not so strong as the day before," he said.
He said the central bank was not considering implementing a crawling peg for the crown at this time.
Late on Thursday the CNB said it had decided to raise its repo rate, but had not set a target for how much it would rise, instead allowing "market conditions" to be the determining factor.
Early on Friday the CNB then announced a one-week repo tender at 12.9 percent, up from 12.4 percent.

Vit said the move was made to allow the repo rate to more reflect the market and that if the central bank had kept its previous rate, "it would be under market and not supporting our aims in today's situation".
Dealers said they thought the move was far too little to provide any real support for the crown.

Just before the repo rate change, the crown was trading at 3.84 percent on the depreciation side of its dollar/mark basket parity. After the announcement, the crown slipped to -3.93 percent. At 1030 GMT the crown was trading at -3.91 percent.
